posts.cooked:
Do all CTRE motor controllers on a single CAN bus have to have different IDs from one another?  In other words, do I have to use different ID numbers if I have a Victor SPX, a Talon SRX, and a Kraken all on the same CAN bus?

I did an experiment and found that Falcon and Krakens must have different ID numbers (or there is a collision).  So this got me wondering if this is true across all the CTRE controllers.  My guess is “yes” given the structure of the CAN packet shown here FRC CAN Device Specifications — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation .

link_counts.title: FRC CAN Device Specifications — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.cooked:
Note that Krakens and Falcons have the same motor controller (TalonFX)

This link I think answers the question: Primer: CTRE CAN Devices — Phoenix documentation

"The device ID is usually expressed as a number between ‘0’ and ‘62’, allowing use for up to 63 Talon SRXs, 63 Victors, 63 PDPs, etc. at once. "

link_counts.title: Primer: CTRE CAN Devices — Phoenix documentation

posts.cooked:
Thanks. It looks like that link you gave does answer the question.  So it seems that each different named CTRE motor controller (e.g. Talon FX) is in a different ID space.  So you could have 63 of each differently named CTRE motor controllers on a single bus.

The only thing this is still curios to me is how this could be achieved given the structure of the FRC CAN packet as shown in FRC CAN Device Specifications — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation .  Given this page, I don’t see how CTRE is able to accomplish this.  There is no place in the packet structure to differentiate between two different families of motor controller (as far as I can tell).  I must be missing something.

link_counts.title: FRC CAN Device Specifications — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.cooked: Interestingly though– TunerX is able to differentiate between krakens and falcons  on the bus (which actually makes this slightly more confusing but its likely due to the same season CTRE says you can have 63 victors and 63 srxs on the same bus)
I think the reason this works is that although they have the same controller, that controller has some hard-coded config info that tells it what motor it is attached. to.

I think this answers a lot of questions:

692.41 KB

Overall I think the answer to the question is that a CAN Frame is not just the 28 bits shown on the WPI CAN doc. That is just the arbitration field of a singular CAN 2.0B frame (if using rio can bus) or a CAN -FD frame (if using a canivore).

Rumboogy:

I think the reason this works is that although they have the same controller, that controller has some hard-coded config info that tells it what motor it is attached. to.

Seems that’s its based on something called “vcmdGetDescriptors” that gets data from dedicated sections of flash Screenshot 2024-01-30 at 2.08.02 AM 2180×964 297 KB
